title: Agumbe Rainforest
short_description: Known as the 'Cherrapunji of the South', a rainforest famous for King Cobras and spectacular sunsets.
long_description: Agumbe is a village located in the Shivamogga district of Karnataka, India. Renowned for its scenic beauty and biodiversity, it is nestled on a plateau on top of Someshwara Ghat. It receives some of the highest rainfall in India, earning it the title 'Cherrapunji of the South'. It is home to the only permanent Rainforest Research Station in India. Agumbe is associated with the King Cobra, the world's longest venomous snake. The sunsets over the Arabian Sea viewed from Agumbe are legendary.
wildlife_significance: King Cobra capital of the world. ARRS (Agumbe Rainforest Research Station) is here.
guides_and_tips: Leeches are guaranteed in wet season. Carry salt. Sunset is best in winter.
how_to_reach: By Air: Mangalore (100 km). By Rail: Udupi (55 km). By Road: Scenic drive from Udupi via Hebri.
permits_and_fees: Falls trekking requires forest dept permission. ARRS is private/research based.
conservation_notes: King Cobra conservation is the primary focus of ARRS.
sample_itinerary: Day 1: Arrive Agumbe. Check in at Dodda Mane. Evening Sunset Point. Day 2: Trek to Onake Abbi Falls. Visit Jogi Gundi Falls. Day 3: Morning walk. Departure.
safety_tips: Do not wander off trails; heavy snake density. Drive carefully on ghat roads.

entry_fees.notes: Forest check post fee for treks.

operating_season.season_notes: Monsoon is beautiful but challenging; travel only if you love rain.
